Chapter 1: Recitation, Part 1 of Chapter 8, Biographies of 21 People with 3 More to Be Seen, Biography of Xing Jian of the Sui Dynasty, Biography of Xing Jian of the Sui Dynasty, Monk Xing Jian, whose place of origin is unknown, always practiced meditation and had a strict moral character. He once traveled east and passed by Mount Tai. It was evening when he entered the mountain temple and planned to spend the night there.
The temple keeper said:
There are no other rooms here, only under the divine corridors.
However, those who come to stay overnight will inevitably suffer a violent death.
Our master should consider this.
Jian said:
No problem.
Having no choice, he followed the keeper's suggestion and made a bed under the corridor.
Jian sat upright and recited the sÅ«tra. After about one watch, he heard the sound of rings and chains from inside the building.
In a moment, the spirit appeared, wearing a magnificent robe and cap, with a dazzling retinue.
He bowed to Sengqie, who said:
I heard that many who stay here die. Could it be that you, the donor, are harming them?
The spirit said:
When I encounter the dead, I go to them. They die by themselves when they hear my voice, I do not kill them.
Please do not worry, Master.
Sengqie invited him to sit and talk.
In a short while, he asked:
It is said that Mount Tai governs ghosts. Is this true?
The spirit said:
I, of little blessings, am in charge of it.
Do you wish to see your deceased relatives?
Sengqie said:
There are two fellow monks who have died. I wish to see them.
The spirit asked their names and said:
One has already been reborn among humans;
the other is in prison being questioned. He cannot be summoned. You can see him if you go there.
When Jian heard this, he was very pleased. He got up and went out not far, and arrived at a place where he saw the flames of the prison fire burning extremely fiercely.

The messengers led Jian into the courtyard, and from afar he saw a person in the fire crying out, unable to speak, his form changed beyond recognition, and the burning stench of blood and flesh made people feel heartbroken.
Jian could not bear to look at it, and felt pity as he sought to leave.
Suddenly, he was in the temple hall again, and he sat with the deity as before.
He asked:
I want to save my fellow student, is there a way?
The deity said:
Yes, you can copy the Lotus Sutra for him, and he will surely be saved.
Soon after, at dawn, the deity took leave of the monk and entered the hall.
When it was morning, the temple warden inspected and found that Jian was not dead, and was amazed.
Jian left and quickly reported his previous wish. After the sutra was copied and bound, he took it and went to the temple to stay overnight.
The spirit appeared as before, joyfully bowed, consoled and inquired about the purpose of the visit, and informed the spirit of the matter.
The spirit said:
I already know, disciple.
When the master wrote the scriptures, as soon as the title was written, they were already freed and reborn in the human realm.
However, this place is not clean, so it is not suitable to keep the scriptures. Please return them to the temple, master.
After saying this, it became dawn, and the spirit took leave and departed. This was during the Daye era.

Biography of Huiguo of Chanding Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Biography of Huiguo of Chanding Temple in Jingzhao, Tang Dynasty Shi Huiguo, unknown clan.

He was simple, silent, respectful, and had a clear and bright mind. He endured hunger and cold, vowing to seek the Great Vehicle.

Biography of Huijing of Chongfu Temple in Taiyuan Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Huijing of Chongfu Temple in Taiyuan Prefecture of the Zhou Dynasty, Shi Huijing, whose surname was Zhang, was a person from Qi.
He was intelligent since childhood. He could speak in swaddling clothes. His parents loved him dearly. The neighbors called him a prodigy.
The newly translated Great Cloud Sutra contained a prophecy about the female ruler. The Empress felt this holy root and cherished this sutra.
At the age of three, he was taught to recite, and his natural talent was outstanding.
He was summoned to the imperial court, where he recited the sutra.
The emperor was greatly delighted and patted his head, bestowing on him a purple robe and later allowing him to leave the household life.
His demeanor was stern, and his studies were firm. He became the head seat of the temple.
He rescued the collapsing rules, and everyone feared and avoided him.
If he saw the two assemblies acting improperly on the streets, causing even a slight scandal, he would certainly discuss punishing them, never being lenient.
Later, he practiced Chan, and a white light appeared in the empty room.
When he passed away, he was over eighty years old.
There is a portrait and a purple robe bestowed on him at the Nine Sons' Mother's Temple.

Biography of Shi Sirui of Chongfu Temple in Taiyuan Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty, Shi Sirui, whose surname was Wang, was a person from Taiyuan.
He was proficient in Chan principles from an early age and also mastered the Vinaya school. He was compassionate, kind, and never showed an angry expression.
Rui was originally frail and sickly, so he set his mind on the Dharma seat, exclusively praying to the Medicine Buddha, diligently and tirelessly.
Soon he saw auspicious signs, and suddenly his mental strength became vigorous, his eloquence flowed like a pouring bottle.
He then recited the Sutra of the Ten Wheels, penetrating several pages a day, the next day doubling it, and later doubling it again. Since then, his sharp wisdom was invincible.
In the Kaiyuan period, he took his staff to Mount Song to inquire about the Way.
At that time, Chan Master Yifu's Chan forest was dense and difficult to enter. With a single word, he entered like a stone thrown into water.
Having drunk the sweet dew, he returned after five years.
Sitting cross-legged in meditation, he did not uncross his knees all day. Those from far and near who came to inquire about the profound principles were like a wall.
He died at the age of 66 in the monastery where he resided.

Biography of Flang of Qinglong Temple in the Upper Capital of the Tang Dynasty, Biography of Flang of Qinglong Temple in the Upper Capital of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Flang was a person from Gusu.
His physical appearance was gentle and moist, and his mind was simple and firm. He recited the Avalokitesvara Spell, and its spiritual efficacy manifested repeatedly.
People in the capital city all knew and respected him.
In the second year of Longshuo, the Princess of Chengyang had a serious illness. She tried all kinds of medicine, but nothing worked.
The princess was the half-sister of Emperor Gaozong, and their friendship was exceptionally deep. She married Du Ruhui's son.
After Du Ruhui died, she remarried to Xue Gu.
When she became seriously ill, someone told her that Liang could recite secret spells and often cured illnesses.
When Liang was summoned and arrived, he set up an altar and recited spells. After a few nights, she felt better, and he was richly rewarded.
The money, silk, and precious treasures Liang received, he gave away to the poor.
The princess reported to the court and requested to change the temple's name to Guanyin Temple, where Liang resided.
This temple was originally Linggan Temple of the Sui Dynasty, established in the third year of the Kaihuang era.
When Emperor Wen moved the capital, he excavated many tombs and graves in the city, and relocated them to the suburbs, and established this temple.
It was abolished during the fourth year of Wude in the Tang Dynasty, and the new name was given to it.
Liang later passed away in this temple.
Tang Dynasty, Hedong Monk Xuan's Biography, Tang Dynasty, Hedong Monk Xuan's Biography, Qi Fang Yuan Guo Monk Xuan of the Tang Dynasty was a person from Bingzhou.
He was originally well-versed in learning, with understanding and practice in harmony.
At the age of ninety-six, he met Chan Master Daoxuan, who wrote the Anleji and lectured on the Guanjing. He then turned his mind to chanting the Buddha's name.
Fearing that his life was coming to an end, he bowed to the Buddha one thousand times day and night, and chanted the name of Amitabha Buddha eight million times.
For five years, he single-mindedly practiced without slacking off.
When he was seriously ill, he told his disciples:
Amitabha Buddha has come to bestow the fragrant robe on me. Avalokitesvara and Mahasthamaprapta are lined up in front. Transformation Buddhas fill the sky.
From here to the west, it is all the Pure Land.
After saying this, he passed away.

At that time, Dharma Master Qifeng and Dharma Master Yuan Guo had a summer retreat at Wuzhen Temple in Lanxi County, where they made a vow to chant the name of Amitabha Buddha together. They broke off a willow branch from the hand of Avalokitesvara and vowed:
If we are able to be reborn in the Buddha's land, we wish that it will not wither for seven days.
When the time came, it was still fresh and green.

He also dreamed of being in a large pond, with a great jeweled curtain to the east. He flew into it and saw monks saying, Just single-mindedly chant the Buddha's name, and you will all be reborn here.
He also saw Avalokitesvara sitting with his feet hanging down.
Fang bowed his head in reverence and saw a pond with lotus flowers. Amitabha Buddha came from the west.
Fang asked the Buddha:
Can sentient beings in Jambudvipa be reborn here by chanting the Buddha's name according to the sutras?
The Buddha said:
Do not doubt, you will definitely be reborn in my land.
He saw that the Land of Ultimate Bliss was level like a mirror, while the SahÄ world was full of mountains and rivers.
The music and jeweled curtains went straight west.
There was a monk named Dharmakara who came in a large cart to welcome him.
Fang saw himself sitting on a lotus flower made of a hundred treasures, attaining perfect enlightenment. Shakyamuni Buddha and Manjushri praised the Lotus Sutra.

He also saw three jeweled stairways leading straight to the west. On the first stairway were all laypeople, on the second stairway were a mixture of laypeople and monks, and on the third stairway were only monks. He said they were all people who had gone to the Pure Land by reciting the Buddha's name.
The two masters Fang and Guo personally said they had seen this.
The Biography of Xuanzang of Baima Temple in Jingzhou during the Tang Dynasty, the Biography of Xuanzang of Baima Temple in Jingzhou during the Tang Dynasty, Shi Xuanzang was a person from Jiangling.

Biography of Hongzheng of the Hermitage in Lingchi County, Chengdu Prefecture, Tang Dynasty. Biography of Hongzheng of the Hermitage in Lingchi County, Chengdu Prefecture, Tang Dynasty. Shi Hongzheng, secular surname Chang, unknown place of origin.
Resided in a hermitage between Min and Shu, had an illness in the past, suffering was prolonged.
After recovering, he vowed to always recite the Diamond Prajna Paramita Sutra, taking twenty times a day as the standard, upholding it diligently without delay.
At that time, the neighboring monk Shouxian sat at night and saw two ghost messengers holding documents in their hands, privately saying to each other:
Take and capture the monk Hongzheng.
One messenger said:
Because he silently recites Prajna, there is great strange protection beside him, no plan can get close to him.
Moreover, I am worried about the delay in the deadline, now I have another plan.

I see someone surnamed Chang who goes out the east gate of the prefecture, who also has the same name as the monk, and who has also been a monk before, come and capture him to fill the vacancy of disobeying the palace.
Shou Xian, hearing this, was shocked and amazed, and determined to do as he was told.
The next day, he secretly asked the gatekeeper, who said that Chang Hongzheng had already died.
Shou Xian previously recited the Amitabha Sutra, but later changed his occupation.
The end of Chang Hongzheng is unknown.
The author says:
Can there be two people with the same name, one alive and one dead?
Karma cannot be changed, but this can be changed, like a shaman drawing a likeness of oneself and saying it can replace one in misfortune and hardship.
The author responds:
King Yama may be a bodhisattva, using the same name to abandon the good and take in the bad.
This may be because the frost of sin suddenly dissipates, and one's lifespan increases, so one can be released;
Or because one's evil vessel is about to be filled, and one's life is about to end, so one is taken.
If one is taken because of a mistake in names, then one can go and teach!
Apart from this, it is not something ordinary people can understand.
Biography of Zhixuan, a Monk of the Tang Dynasty. The monk Zhixuan was a man from Heshuo.
He studied the five heavenly prohibitions and spells, and only wore hemp cloth.
He traveled through various states and counties, not staying in city temples, but only lodging in the forests on the outskirts.
Zhixuan had the intention of seeking out famous sites. When he arrived in Jiangzhou, he stayed in a forest by a tomb at night.
That night the moonlight was like daytime. He saw a fox from the forest taking a skull and placing it on its head. It did not care about the fallen ones, but wore the ones that did not fall.
It took some grass and fallen leaves to cover its body. In a short while, it became a charming young woman, wearing a plain silk dress all over her body, standing on the side of the road.
She faintly heard the sound of horses and riders coming from the northeast. The woman wept sadly, unable to contain herself.
After a short while, a horseman encountered her and dismounted to ask:
Lady, why are you crying so bitterly in the wilderness at this late hour?
The woman covered her tears and lied, saying:

This humble concubine's family is in Yishui. Two years ago, my parents betrothed me to Zhang's family in this land as a wife. Unfortunately, my husband passed away last year. The family affairs are in decline, and I have no one to rely on.
How could my parents know that I am so lonely and suffering like this?
If there is one here, it would be a painful stab to the heart. I can't help but grieve and wail.
I think of returning to my parents' home, but is it possible?
Why do you ask in such a strange way?
The horseman said:
I thought the lady was grieving over something else. If you wish to return home, I am a messenger returning to Yishui on official business for Yiding Army. The lady can ride on my crude mount.
The woman then wiped away her tears and thanked him.
Just as she was about to climb up, Xuan came out of the tomb grove and said:
Sir, this woman is not human, she is a fox in disguise.
He said:
How can the monks be falsely accused of this?
Do you have other plans for them?
Xuan said:
If you don't believe it, you can stay a little longer.
I will transform the woman back to her original form for you.
Xuan then shook his staff and recited some Sanskrit words several times. The woman turned back into a fox and ran away, while the grass covering her skull remained.
The horseman kowtowed and repented:
If it weren't for the master's rescue, I would have almost died with the demon.
Xuan's acts of saving beings and practicing compassion were all of this kind.
The Biography of Yuanjiao of Kaiyuan Temple in Fengxiang Prefecture of the Tang Dynasty. Shi Yuanjiao was a man from Lingwu.
He had integrity and was not the same as the crowd, taking upholding the esoteric teachings as his own duty.
At the end of the Tianbao era, Emperor Xuanzong fled to Shu, and Empress Xu was training troops in Lingwu, planning to retake the capital.
The opinions of the people were unanimous, requesting the emperor to ascend the throne and change the era name to Zhide.
In the second year, he returned to Fufeng. The Emperor, who had long relied on Buddhism, selected the foremost monks of pure conduct, as if to cleanse and remove impurities.
The one recommended by the people of Xihe in the north was Jiao, who was summoned to receive the imperial decree and followed the imperial carriage to the capital.
The Emperor then ordered Jiao to depart earlier and arrived at Fengxiang, where he established the Imperial Medicine Master Altar at Kaiyuan Temple.

He further selected thirty-seven monks to practice the six periods of worship, light lamps, sing praises, chant sutras, and no one dared to say they were tired. Their purity and sincerity were immeasurable.
Suddenly, a cluster of plum trees grew inside the Dharma assembly, with forty-nine stems. The matter was reported to the Emperor, who sent an imperial messenger to verify its authenticity.
The Emperor was greatly surprised and delighted, saying:
This is a great auspicious response.

On the eighteenth day of the fourth month, the monks who had inspected and recited the Imperial Medicine Master Altar, headed by Yuan Jiao, submitted a memorial to congratulate the Emperor, to which the Emperor replied:
The abundant auspicious plums are a sign of the nation's prosperity.
Being born within the monastery, he knew the glory of the Bodhi tree.
Feeling this auspicious sign, he celebrates together with the master.
Jiao's recitation had many such instances of effective spiritual responses.
He was appointed as a court chaplain.

Tang Dynasty Biographies of Eminent Monks, Scroll 10, Biography of Chu Jin of Qianfu Temple in the Capital, Tang Dynasty, Biography of Chu Jin of Qianfu Temple in the Capital, Tang Dynasty, Shi Chu Jin, son of the Cheng family, originally from Guangping Prefecture, now from Baxi in Jingzhao Prefecture.
His mother, Lady Gao, dreamed of buddhas at night and became pregnant. He was truly the son of the Dharma King.
His conduct was pure like jade, his spirit was harmonious and his temperament was pure.
At seven years old, he recited the Lotus Sutra. At eighteen, he understood its meaning.
At thirty, he built a pagoda called Multi-Treasure.

At forty, he entered the emperor's dream in the nine-storied palace. Xuanzong saw the golden characters under the Dharma name, and the next morning, the messengers inquired, all believing it to be true.
At that time, the sound spread throughout the capital, and people were recruited to build a pagoda. It was completed in stages, as if turning one's palm.
He once climbed the verdant peaks and spiritual peaks of Wuzhen, and said:

Auspicious birds of golden and azure colors perch in his hands;

On the seventh day of the seventh month in the second year of Ganyuan, he passed away on his right side.
When the firewood is exhausted, the fire is extinguished. The snow-like face is as if present, brightly ascending to the country of peace and bliss.
He was sixty-two years old, and had been a monk for thirty-seven years.
The Son of Heaven pitied him, and a central envoy consoled him.

The emperor ordered Cavalry General Zhu Guanghui to take care of him. He was then buried according to his Buddhist rites on the west side of the city, at the Fahua hermitage on Longshouyuan, and a stupa was erected.
When Jin was a young boy, he copied the Lotus Sutra. He did not wear silk, but only added cotton padding when it was cold.
His disciples Huikong, Fahan, and Haoran were all like the sons of the elephant king.
The inscription on the flying staff at Caotang Temple on Zige Peak, written by Wu Tongwei.

On the thirteenth day of the fourth month in the thirteenth year of the Zhenyuan era, Dou Wenchang, the Chief Minister of Merit of the Left Street and Duke of Bin State, reported, The late master Chu Jin of Qianfu Temple was the monk of this subject. He built the Multi-Treasure Pagoda for the country in the beginning of the Tianbao era and established the Lotus Sutra Dharma Assembly, which has continued for over sixty years.
The monks chant and pay homage during the six periods of the day, and the sound of sutra recitation never ceases. It has passed through four reigns, but no imperial grace has been bestowed.
The edict bestowed the posthumous title of Great Perfection Chan Master.

The Biography of Shi Daxing, a Great Practitioner of Mount Tai in Yanzhou during the Tang Dynasty. Shi Daxing was a person from Qizhou.
